Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Story: I was sitting on the couch with my stepfamily, half-listening as they tossed around ideas for our weekend together—hiking, a movie night, maybe even a day trip to the lake. My stepmom smiled at me, her eyes hopeful, and I knew she wanted me to chime in, to show I was part of the family. I tried to focus, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a call from my best friend, Mia. I slipped away to answer, and her voice was shaky, barely holding back sobs. She’d just gotten terrible news about her dad, and she needed me—needed someone to listen, to just be there. I could hear my stepbrother calling me back to the living room, asking which plan I liked best. My stepmom’s voice followed, gentle but expectant. I stood in the hallway, phone pressed to my ear, torn between the warmth of my new family and the pain in my friend’s voice, feeling the weight of both worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
